title: 114_s1600
content: The Act titled "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. Exclusive remedies under this section are limited to designated Federal agencies or components. The "Judicial Redress Act of 2015" extends Privacy Act remedies to citizens of designated countries, allowing covered persons to bring civil actions against agencies for intentional or willful disclosures in violation of the Act. Exclusive remedies under this section are limited to designated Federal agencies or components. Covered persons have the same rights and limitations as individuals under section 552a of title 5, United States Code, when pursuing civil remedies. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country or regional economic integration organization. The Attorney General, with the concurrence of other officials, may designate a foreign country or regional economic integration organization as a "covered country" if they have agreed to privacy protections for shared information or if deemed necessary for preventing criminal offenses. The Attorney General can designate a foreign country as a "covered country" if they have shared information with the US for preventing criminal offenses and have privacy protections. The designation can be revoked with the concurrence of other officials. The Attorney General can revoke the designation of a foreign country as a "covered country" if it does not comply with agreements, no longer meets requirements, or hinders information transfer to the US by private entities. The Attorney General determines if an agency or component is a "designated federal agency." The Attorney General determines if an agency or component is a "designated Federal agency or component" for purposes of information transfer to the United States by a private entity or person. The Attorney General can designate an agency as a "designated Federal agency" for exchanging information with a covered country or if it is in the law enforcement interests of the United States. The Attorney General can designate an agency as a "designated Federal agency" for exchanging information with a covered country or if it is in the law enforcement interests of the United States. The determinations made under this designation are published in the Federal Register and are not subject to judicial or administrative review. The United States District Court for the District of Columbia has exclusive jurisdiction over any claims arising under this section. The term "agency" refers to the meaning in section 552(f) of title 5, United States Code. A "covered country" is a country or regional economic organization designated in accordance with subsection (d). A "covered person" is a non-individual citizen of a covered country. A "covered record" has the same meaning as a record under section 552a of title 5, United States Code, once transferred by a public authority or private entity within a covered country. Once a covered record is transferred by a public authority or private entity from a covered country to a designated Federal agency for criminal investigation, the individual's information is protected under section 552a of title 5, United States Code. The term "individual" is defined in section 552a(a)(2) of title 5, United States Code. The Act designates agencies for handling records, defines "individual," preserves privileges, and sets an effective date.
